text: This IRM is part of the Servicewide effort to provide IRS Human Resource practitioners with the most current policies and procedures from the Human Capital Office, Employment, Talent and Security Division.

, the following guidance has been superseded:

IRM 6.300.1, Appointment Determinations and Policies, dated August 1, 2002, has been superseded. Current and applicable guidance previously found in IRM 6.300.1 and other official Servicewide have been moved to this and other IRMs, which have been renumbered to follow the numbering format in Title 5 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). In addition to IRM 6.300.1, the following guidance has been superseded:
a. Policy 10, Use of Seasonal Work Schedules, Amended December 30, 2003 b. Policy 66, Part-Time Career Employment Program, dated July 21, 2004
) IRM

provides Servicewide policy, standards, requirements, and guidance relating to the administration of other than full-time employment. This IRM must be read and interpreted in accordance with pertinent law, Governmentwide regulations, Treasury Human Resources and applicable case law. All previous official Servicewide policy, formerly contained in memoranda, guides, and other documents are incorporated into this IRM, if current and applicable. (

) For employees in bargaining units covered by negotiated agreements, appropriate negotiated agreement provisions relating to subjects in this Chapter should also be reviewed. For bargaining employees, should any of these instructions conflict with a provision of a negotiated agreement, agreement will prevail.

IRM 6.340.1 provides Servicewide policy, standards, requirements, and guidance relating to the administration of other than full-time employment. This IRM must be read and interpreted in accordance with pertinent law, Governmentwide regulations, Treasury Human Resources and applicable case law. All previous official Servicewide policy, formerly contained in memoranda, guides, and other documents are incorporated into this IRM, if current and applicable.

For employees in bargaining units covered by negotiated agreements, appropriate negotiated agreement provisions relating to subjects in this Chapter should also be reviewed. For bargaining unit employees, should any of these instructions conflict with a provision of a negotiated agreement, the agreement will prevail.

was lished to continually provide career part-time employment opportunities and provide management the flexibility to maximize the use of human capital. Department of Treasury delegated IRS responsibility for establishing and taining a part-time career program. Title
USC §
provides the foundation for agencies to establish a part-time career opportunity program. (

) This IRM describes less than full-time career employment and the IRS time Career Employment Program, which applies to all IRS organizational components and employees, unless otherwise stated. Negotiated may amend, supersede, or supplement agency guidelines. (

) Seasonal Employment - Annually recurring work periods of less than
months each year. Seasonal employees are permanent employees who placed in non-duty/non-pay status and recalled to duty in accordance with established conditions of employment. (

) Intermittent Employment - Employment without a regularly scheduled tour duty. An intermittent work schedule is appropriate only when the nature of work is sporadic and unpredictable so that a tour of duty cannot be scheduled in advance. (
) Part-Time Career Employment - Regularly scheduled work from
to

) The Federal Employees Part-Time Career Employment Act of

was estab- lished to continually provide career part-time employment opportunities and to provide management the flexibility to maximize the use of human capital. The Department of Treasury delegated IRS responsibility for establishing and main- taining a part-time career program. Title
USC §
provides the foundation for agencies to establish a part-time career opportunity program. (

) This IRM describes less than full-time career employment and the IRS Part- time Career Employment Program, which applies to all IRS organizational components and employees, unless otherwise stated. Negotiated agreements may amend, supersede, or supplement agency guidelines. (

Mixed tour of Duty - A work schedule that may be changed from full-time, part-time, or intermittent to accommodate workloads.

Other Than Full-Time Career a. The term “part-time career employment” does not apply to employees appointments in tenure groups I or II who work under mixed tours of duty. b. For this purpose, a mixed tour of duty consists of annually recurring periods of full-time, part-time, or intermittent service as long as the employee does not work part-time more than
pay periods per calendar year. (

) “The Manager’s Guide to Hiring a Less Than Full-time Workforce” provides information on various appointment types, work schedules, seasonal agree- to ments, benefits, probationary periods, recruitment options, etc. Useful web Than links are provided throughout the document that can further assist with many of the employment-related questions that may impact less than full-time employees. (
) To locate the “Manager’s Guide to Hiring a Less Than Full-time Workforce” go to:http://hco.web.irs.gov/recruitstaff/externalhire/filingseason/worksched/index.html (
) “Seasonal” identifies a work schedule and is not an appointment type. Seasonal employment is appropriate when the work recurs predictably year and is expected to last at least
months during a calendar year. The season must be defined as closely as possible so that an employee will have reasonably clear idea of how much work can be expected. A seasonal ment agreement (Form
, Seasonal Employment Agreement), must be executed between management and the seasonal employee prior to the em- ployee’s entering on duty in accordance with
CFR §
) IRS may assign seasonal employees to other seasonal work in lieu of releasing the employee during the projected layoff period. Title

CFR Part provides for the placement of seasonal employees who have completed the season for which they were hired into other seasonal positions. Employees may be reassigned at the end of the first season to another position with a different season and a new seasonal employment agreement. (
) The movement of employees to provide continued employment might result in

months or more of continuous employment. Employees are allowed to more than one season provided they have completed the season for which they were hired. The following applies to extended seasons and is subject to merit promotion procedures: a. Movement to a higher graded position; or b. Movement to a position with promotion potential. (

) Managers should complete an addendum to the seasonal employment agreement that spells out the new season and position. The addendum be attached to the original agreement and filed with the employee’s manager. (

) The Service’s other than full time workforce has typically been career condi- tional appointments with a seasonal work schedule; though seasonal work schedules can also be used with temporary and term appointments. Less full-time employment encompasses work schedules that are seasonal, part- time, intermittent, or mixed tours of duty. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
G
6.340 Other Than Full-Time Career

The term “part-time career employment” does not apply to employees with appointments in tenure groups I or II who work under mixed tours of duty. For this purpose, a mixed tour of duty consists of annually recurring periods of full-time, part-time, or intermittent service as long as the employee does not work part-time more than
pay periods per calendar year.
Career Employment and Intermittent)
) It is important to note that if a career/career-conditional seasonal employee worked continuously in the same position for a full year, the work schedule the position should be made non-seasonal. (
) The IRS Part-time Career Employment Program provides part-time career ployment opportunities to the maximum extent possible based on resources and mission requirements for positions up to the GS-
or equivalent, payband positions as determined by each business unit. Business units establish goals and timetables to determine the availability of part-time ment opportunities. (

) The Program is administered without regard to race, color, religion, national origin, politics, marital status, age, non-disqualifying physical handicap, orientation, personal favoritism, membership or non-membership in an employee organization, or activity or office in an employee organization. (
) The program is used in conjunction with the negotiated agreement. (

) Part-time employment is not limited to specific positions. Management may any position when the arrangement meets the needs of the organization the mission of the Service. The Program covers encumbered positions with regularly scheduled tour of duty of
hours a week in either the tive or excepted service of Tenure Group I or II. (

) Recruiting for part-time career employees enables management to plan and meet the workload needs of the operation. For example, sites scheduled to ramp down within the next few years might consider using part-time or seasonal temporary or term appointments, with not-to-exceed dates that precede the ramp down dates. (

) Permanent part-time employment also provides for employees: a. Gradual transition into retirement for retirement eligibles; b. Employment opportunities to individuals with disabilities; c. Employment opportunities to others who require a reduced work week; d. Employment opportunities to parents who need to balance family bilities with the need for additional income; and e. Employment opportunities for students who must finance their own education or vocational training. (

) Part-time employment opportunities must be clearly stated in the vacancy nouncement and on external public vacancy announcements. When have been identified as part-time, management should permit employees to request and receive consideration to change from full-time to part-time whenever feasible. This is considered a non-competitive action. (

) Employees in covered positions must meet qualification and eligibility ments in accordance with the Office of Personnel Management Operating Manual for Qualification Standards for General Schedule Positions.
Than Full-Time Career Employment Seasonal, and Intermittent) 6.340.1

The IRS Part-time Career Employment Program provides part-time career em- ployment opportunities to the maximum extent possible based on resources and mission requirements for positions up to the GS-15 or equivalent, including payband positions as determined by each business unit. Business units establish goals and timetables to determine the availability of part-time employ- ment opportunities.
Part
time employment opportunities must be clearly stated in the vacancy an
nouncement and on external public vacancy announcements. When positions have been identified as part
time, management should permit employees to request and receive consideration to change from full
time to part
time whenever feasible. This is considered a non
competitive action. Employees in covered positions must meet qualification and eligibility require
Other Than Full-Time Career (

) Part-time employees have the same rights as full-time employees in actions relating to discipline or performance. Adverse and performance-based include suspensions, removals, furloughs and reduction in grade. (

) An involuntary reduction in the tour-of-duty for part-time employees is an adverse action; accordingly, care should be taken in setting the tour-of-duty a level that can be maintained throughout the year. (
) A full-time employee is not required to accept a part-time position as a condition of continued employment. (

) Part-time and part-time job-sharing employees have assignment rights only part-time positions and compete separately from full-time employees during reduction-in-force (RIF). Full-time employees have assignment rights only to full-time positions and cannot displace a part-time employee. (
) Temporary increases in the work hours for part-time employees may be effective for no more than two pay periods. These temporary increases do require documentation with an SF-
, Notification of Personnel Action. Increases which will extend beyond two pay periods are considered the tour-of-duty and should be documented on the SF-
with an Not to Exceed (NTE) date. (

) Employees should be notified of the following when applying for part-time positions. a. The government contribution for the health benefit premium is prorated. For example, a part-time employee who has a
-hour work week will receive one-half (
hours/
hours) of the normal government tion. b. In determining qualifications, part-time employment is credited based on the relation it bears to the normal work week (
hours per week). That an employee who has one year of experience at

hours per week will receive credit for six months of experience. c. In determining eligibility requirements and eligibility for a within-grade increase, part-time employment is credited on a calendar basis. That is, is credited at the same rate as full-time employment. (

) Employees participating in the Part-time Career Employment Program are entitled to earn overtime pay, compensatory time, leave for religious obser- vance, holiday pay or other rights in accordance with applicable law and regulations. Over time rates apply only to hours in excess of eight hours in day or
hours in a week. (

) Job sharing is covered under the Part-time Employment Program since the schedules of two part-time employees are arranged to cover the duties of a single full-time position. It provides an opportunity for employees to work time when management has determined that the position requires full-time coverage. Any position may be filled by a single part-time employee or more than one part-time employee when the arrangements meet the needs of the IRS. (
) Job sharing flexibility provides: a. Coverage during another job share employee’s absence; Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
G

Than Full-Time Career Employment Seasonal, and Intermittent) 6.340.1
b. Extra hours of work to be performed when there are unexpected workloads; and c. Opportunities for job share employees to build individual strengths. (

) Though more than one employee may share the responsibility for the position, each employee participating in job sharing is required to have her own: a. Performance plan; b. Critical job elements; and c. Evaluation of his or her performance relating to the performance standards. (

) Each business operating division’s annual human capital planning should include the use of part-time and job sharing positions when it is in best interest of the organization. Consideration should be given to: (cid:
) Workload fluctuations; (cid:
) Employment ceilings and budgetary considerations; (cid:
) Size of the workforce; (cid:
) Turnover rate and employment trends; (cid:
) Vacant positions and availability of qualified applicants willing to work time; (cid:
) Potential for improving service to the public; and (cid:
) Other local needs.
